The human body contains trillions and trillions of micro-organisms. According to the editorial piece, "A Universe of Us", the number of bacteria (100 trillion) in the human body is actually greater than the number of human cells (10 trillion). Most of these bacteria are not harmful, but instead helpful to human development. Humans are all in beneficial symbiotic relationships with the microorganisms that live inside their bodies. The bacteria have a habitat and access to food, and in turn give humans regular bodily functions. According to Dr. Sanjay Gupta's magazine article, "Eat Your Germs", "In the digestive tract, the bacteria help regulate and restore peristalsis, the rhythmic motion of the intestine that pushes digested food through."

The statement means that even though each individual may seem to be an individual example of the human genome, those individuals are a part of a larger genome of humans. Brody paraphrases Dr. Mary Ruebush, who "points out that bacteria are everywhere: on us, in us and all around us" (Source #1). Even though each individual may think of him or herself as an individual, he or she is the same as everyone else, since each person has bacterina outside the body, inside the body and all around the body. Furthermore, Michael Spector from The New Yorker states in his article, "Germs Are US," "Helicobacter pylori may be the most successful pathogen in human history" (Source #3). Spector states that the helicobacter pyroli pathogen has been a part of human history, just as "the bacteria that cause tuberculosis, cholera, and the plague" has been a part of human history (Source #3). By saying that those diseases has been a part of human history, Spector implies that since each human is a part of history, each individual is a part of the whole history.

Deoxy riboneuclaic acid, or DNA, is made up of four different bases. These bases (G,A,T, and C) do not change for any one species, in fact every living thing is made up of that swirling double helix. In the article, from the New York Times, "A Universe Of Us" the writer states that "We are not just the expression of an individual human genome," and he's right. The human genome shares 2% of its code with bannas, 5% of its code with gerbils, 90% with gorrillas, and between I, the writer, and everyone else in the world, there is a 1% difference in our genetic code. We don't even realilze that bacteria that "spur the development of a healthy immune system," and the germs that "play such a crucial in our lives," (these quotes are from the articles "Babies Know: A Little Dirt is Good for You", and " Eat Your Germs" respectivly) share the same bases in their small genetic code as we do ours. We are so connected, not even by the relationships and ecosystems we live in but even more closely by the DNA and genetic make up's we share.
